item.title: Somers' Arms, Eastnor
item.description:
The Somers' Arms, Eastnor seems to be named after the Somers-Cocks family, lords of the manor of Eastnor. Another family of by the name of Somers/Summers had also been long resident in the parish.  They were small farmers and labourers.

It developed from a small farmstead, known in the 1770s as Summers  or Somers Farm. By 1816 at least,  it was known as the Somers Arms, the tenant combining farming with providing refreshment to travellers on the turnpike road between Ledbury and Tewksbury. The current house dates to c.1810-1820, although it may incorporate some older building. The stables predate 1840 and in the1850s a large coverd yard for cattle was built. This is now used as business premises.

In the later 19th century, when the estate was held by Lady Henry Somerset, a leading temperance campaigner, it was a Temperance Hotel.It continued as such until the Second World War.
item.dc:creator: SylviaP

item.title: Eastnor Probate Material 1701 and later
item.description:
The volume of surviving probate material increases after 1701, but the value of the documents to the local and the social historian declines as gradually the number of inventories deccreases and as testators tended to make less detailed disposition of their household and personal belongings. Consequently a systematic transcription of probate material has not been undertaken. The material relating to important people in the parish, particularly the rectors and the lords of the manor, will be added as they come to hand.

William Stone, rector, 1701

John Traherne, rector, 1751
item.dc:creator: SylviaP

item.title: Eastnor Probate Material 1681-1700
item.description:
There are 13 surviving probate records for Eastnor people in the period 1681-1700, of which eight have both will and inventory. There are three wills and two inventories with no other documents. None of them have accounts.

The two women were both widows, one the widow of a gentleman and one the widow of a yeoman. Both husbands' wills also survive. Of the 11 men, occupations or status are given for ten of them: a gentleman, seven yeomen, a weaver and a carpenter. There is a gap in the Eastnor burial registers from June 1678 to April 1734, so no additional information has been gleaned from the registers. The wills and inventories are for:

Richard Summers, yeoman, 1681 (inventory)

Gilbert James, gentleman, 1681(will & inventory)

Thomas Walter, yeoman, 1684 (nuncupative will & inventory)

John Jauncey, yeoman, 1685 (will & inventory)

John Dugmore, yeoman, 1685 (will)

Thomas Baldwyn, yeoman, 1686 (will & inventory)

Henry Aston, yeoman, 1687 (will & inventory)

Thomas Richards, 1687 (will & inventory)

Margaret Morton, widow, 1688 (will)

William Bache, weaver, 1688 (will & inventory)

Jane Asston, widow, 1691 (will & inventory)

Edward Bucknell, yeoman, 1693 (will)

William Burroppe, carpenter, 1694 (inventory)
item.dc:creator: SylviaP

item.title: Eastnor Probate Material 1661-1680
item.description:
There are probate documents for 18 Eastnor people during the period 1661-1680. As for many other places, the probate documents that survive from this period are particularly full, many of the wills having accompanying probate inventories. Five of these Eastnor sets of documents include accounts, showing how the executors administered the estate, even giving the cost of the funeral in some cases. They are for:

Henry Tomkins, labourer, 1664 (inventory & account)

John Webley, yeoman & carpenter, 1665 (will & inventory)

Anthony Bache the elder, tailor, 1665 (will & inventory)

William Alderne, yeoman, 1667 (will & inventory)

Thomas Pewtress, bachelor, 1667 (will & inventory)

John Bauldwine, yeoman, 1667 (will & inventory)

William Hartland, yeoman, 1668 (inventory)

Daniel Jauncey, husbandman, 1669 (inventory & account)

John Pewtress, 1670 (administration and inventory)

Humphrey Morton, gentleman, 1671 (will & inventory)

Elizabeth Dugmore, single woman, 1671 (will & inventory)

Anthony Bache 1672, (inventory & account)

Francis Bradford, tailor, 1676 (inventory & account)

William Burford, husbandman, (inventory & account)

Robert Higgins of Hillend, gentleman, 1678 (will & inventory)

John Collins, yeoman, 1678 (will)

Robert Summers, 1679 (inventory & account)

Richard Coke, clerk, 1680, (will)
item.dc:creator: SylviaP

item.title: Eastnor Probate Material 1641-1660
item.description:
There are only four surviving wills  for Eastnor people for this period, covering the English Civil War and the Commonwealth. Apart from the disruption and anxiety caused by the war, the system of ecclesiastical courts, which had jurisdiction over probate, was dismantled during the Commonwealth. From 1653 until the Restoration in 1660 all wills had to be proved at the Prerogative Court of Canterbury. In fact, all four of the Eastnor wills of this period were proved there.

Richard Underwood, 1647

Thomas Danford, 1652

John Dugmore, 1653

Margery Parry, 1655
item.dc:creator: SylviaP

item.title: Eastnor Probate Material 1621-1640
item.description:
There are only nine surviving wills for Eastnor people from the period 1621-1640.Four of them are nuncupative wills, oral statements of the deceased's intentions before credible witnesses, who then swore to the truth of the statment in the probate court. Three are for members of the same family, two brothers and the son of one of them. The status of the testators ranges widely from Richard Turner, status not given, through a husbandmen, three yeomen, a gentleman and an esquire.

Richard Cocks, esquire, 1623

Henry Perry, husbandman, 1623

Thomas Baulden, yeoman, 1624

Simon Lawrence, yeoman, 1626

Leonard Branch, narrow weaver, 1632

Thomas Branch, 1635

Rowland Braunch, yeoman, 1636

Thomas Higgins, gentleman, 1637

Richard Turner, 1639
item.dc:creator: SylviaP

item.title: Eastnor Probate Material 1601-1620
item.description:
There are 13 surviving wills for Eastnor people in this period. None have accompanying inventories, but many of the wills give a great deal of information about farming stock and household goods. There is only one woman amongst them, a widow. The majority of the them appear to have been involved with agriculture, at least to some degree, but there are also a timberman, adyer and a weaver, a servant, and the rector of Eastnor.

William Rickards, yeoman, 1607

Elinor Shaw, widow, 1607

Walter Belamy, 1607

John Ford, timberman, 1609

John Morse, dyer, 1612

William Batche, webster [weaver], 1613

Richard Careless, yeoman, 1614

Humphrey Collins, 1614

William Houlder, husbandman, 1614

John Weobley the elder, husbandman, 1614

Thomas Brooke, servant, 1616

William Saintbarbe, clerk, 1619

Anthony Lawrence, 1620
item.dc:creator: SylviaP

item.title: Eastnor Probate Material 1581 - 1600
item.description:
There are 14 surviving wills for Eastnor people, all men, between 1581 and 1600. Although none of them have accompanying inventories, they all contain a geat deal of information about farming (cattle, crops and implements), tools of trade and household goods. A number include detailed lists of debts owed by and to the testator, which help to piece together the dense web of connections between people in Elizabethan Herefordshire. Although the gap in the burial registers 1579-90 means that the deaths of many cannot be dated, other surviving documents (court rolls, rentals and deeds) can supply more information about some of the people. The wills are for:

John Branche, 1583

John Elcox, yeoman, 1588

Thomas Hopley, 1588

Edmund Underwood, 1590

Thomas Burnell, 1590

Richard Bache, husbandman, 1591

Richard Gray, husbandman, 1591

John Webley, yeoman, 1592

Robert Danford, 1593

William Pivar, smith, 1595

Gilbert Collins, labourer, 1596

Gabriel Williams, labourer, 1596

Richard Braunche, husbandman, 1597

Christopher Hopley, 1597
item.dc:creator: SylviaP

item.title: Eastnor Probate Material 1561 - 1580
item.description:
There are 11 surviving probate documents for the period 1561 - 1580, two for women and nine for men. As the Eastnor burial registers begin in 1561, although with a gap from 1579 to 1591, it has been possible to identify some of the testators. Where this is the case, a note has been made at the end of the transcript.

During this period a number of the wills take on a decidedly Protestant tone, stressing belief in redemption solely through the death of Jesus Christ. Such is the will of William Clifton, shoemaker, who described himself as 'the improfitable servant of God' and who went on to stress his belief 'nothing doubting but that this my lord God for his mercies sake, set forth in the precious blood of his dearly beloved son Christ Jesu our alone saviour and redeemer, will forgive me all mine offences, and receive my soul into his glory.'

Much can be learned from these wills and inventories about everyday life, too. Farming stock, crops and implements are listed, as are household goods and personal items. Anne Hopley, a young woman, left specific items of clothing to her aunts. Alice Bache left cows named Lilly, Filpail and Mullins to her daughters. John Webley left detailed instructions about his household furnishings, including painted cloths, some of which were to remain as 'standards' in his house, that is, were not to be removed but passed down with the house.

Roger Tarte, will, 1564

Thomas Webley, husbandman, will, 1564

William Clifton, shoemaker, will and inventory, 1565

Anne Hopley, will, 1565

Thomas Carre, probate, 1568

Robert Aston, alias Glover, will, 1572

John a Lye, will, 1572

Thomas Turner, yeoman, will, 1572

Thomas Clinton, esquire, will, 1572

Alice Bache, wife of John Bache the elder, will, 1579

John Webley, will, 1579
item.dc:creator: SylviaP

item.title: Eastnor Probate Material 1501-1540
item.description:
There are 12 probate records for Eastnor people during the first forty years of the 16th century. Eleven of them are listed in Calendar of Probate and Administration Acts 1407-1541 and Abstracts of Wills 1541-1581 in the Court Books of the Bishop of Hereford, edited by M.A. Faraday and E.J.L. Coles with introduction and index compiled by M.A. Faraday British Record Society, London, 1989. The twelfth is that of John Clinton in 1502. He was a wealthy man and held the manor of Barton in Henmarsh, Worcestershire, as well as an estate in Eastnor. As he held property in more than one diocese his will had to be proved at the Prerogative Court of Canterbury and the enrolled copy of this is preserved at the National Archives.

John Clinton, 1502, will

Richard Tippyng, 1514, Calendar entry

Richard Fowle, 1523, Calendar entry

Thomas Dogmor, 1523, Calendar entry

Agnes Pole, 1530, Calendar entry

Alice Bache, 1530, Calendar entry

Elizabeth West, 1530, Calendar entry

Thomas Dugmore, 1530, Calendar entry

William Woodward, 1534, Calendar entry

Henry Braynche, 1535, Calendar entry

William Clynton, esquire, 1535, Calendar entry

Roger Turnor, 1540, Calendar entry
